workflow.name: replace_weather_file
workflow.description: Sets the EPW weather file (EPW), supplemental data specific to the location, and daylight saving time start/end dates.

workflow.name: create_bar_from_space_type_ratios
workflow.display_name: Create Bar From Space Type Ratios
workflow.measure_definition_display_name: Create Bar From Space Type Ratios
workflow.description: Creates one or more rectangular building elements based on space type ratios of selected mix of building types, along with user arguments that describe the desired geometry characteristics.

arguments.name: space_type_hash_string
arguments.default_value: MediumOffice | Conference => 0.2, PrimarySchool | Corridor => 0.125, PrimarySchool | Classroom => 0.175, Warehouse | Office => 0.5

arguments.display_name: Ratio of North/South Facade Length Relative to East/West Facade Length
arguments.name: ns_to_ew_ratio

arguments.display_name: Fraction of Exterior Wall Area with Adjacent Structure
arguments.name: party_wall_fraction

arguments.display_name: Number of North facing stories with party wall
arguments.name: party_wall_stories_north

arguments.display_name: Number of South facing stories with party wall
arguments.name: party_wall_stories_south

arguments.display_name: Number of East facing stories with party wall
arguments.name: party_wall_stories_east

arguments.display_name: Number of West facing stories with party wall
arguments.name: party_wall_stories_west

arguments.display_name: Is the Bottom Story Exposed to Ground
arguments.name: bottom_story_ground_exposed_floor

arguments.display_name: Is the Top Story an Exterior Roof
arguments.name: top_story_exterior_exposed_roof

arguments.display_name: Make Mid Story Floor Surfaces Adiabatic
arguments.name: make_mid_story_surfaces_adiabatic

arguments.display_name: Division Method for Bar Space Types
arguments.name: bar_division_method
arguments.default_value: Multiple Space Types - Individual Stories Sliced
arguments.value: Multiple Space Types - Individual Stories Sliced

workflow.name: create_typical_building_from_model
workflow.description: Takes a model with space and stub space types, and assigns constructions, schedules, internal loads, hvac, and other loads such as exterior lights and service water heating.

arguments.display_name: Kitchen Exhaust MakeUp Air Calculation Method
arguments.name: kitchen_makeup

arguments.display_name: Add Space Type Loads to Model
arguments.name: add_space_type_loads

arguments.display_name: Add Service Water Heating to Model
arguments.name: add_swh

workflow.name: add_hourly_meters
workflow.description: This measure adds hourly meters for the most common energy use types.

workflow.name: increase_insulation_r_value_for_exterior_walls
workflow.display_name: Increase R-value of Insulation for Exterior Walls to a Specific Value
workflow.measure_definition_display_name: Increase R-value of Insulation for Exterior Walls to a Specific Value
workflow.description: Set the R-Value of exterior wall insulation to a specified value.  Higher R-Values provide better insulation, lowering heat loss and heat gain through the exterior walls. Costs for a construction can be adjusted

arguments.display_name: Allow both increase and decrease in wall R-value to reach requested target?
arguments.name: allow_reduction

arguments.display_name: Increase in Wall Material and Installation Costs for Construction per Area Used ($/ft^2).
arguments.name: material_cost_increase_ip

arguments.display_name: One Time Retrofit Cost to Add Wall Insulation to Construction ($/ft^2).
arguments.name: one_time_retrofit_cost_ip

arguments.display_name: Year to Incur One Time Retrofit Cost (whole years).
arguments.name: years_until_retrofit_cost

workflow.name: increase_insulation_r_value_for_roofs
workflow.display_name: Increase R-value of Insulation for Roofs to a Specific Value
workflow.measure_definition_display_name: Increase R-value of Insulation for Roofs to a Specific Value
workflow.description: Set the R-Value of roof insulation to a specified value.  Higher R-Values provide better insulation, lowering heat loss and heat gain through the roof.

arguments.display_name: Allow both increase and decrease in roof R-value to reach requested target?
arguments.name: allow_reduction

arguments.display_name: Increase in Roof Material and Installation Costs for Construction per Area Used ($/ft^2).
arguments.name: material_cost_increase_ip

arguments.display_name: One Time Retrofit Cost to Add Roof Insulation to Construction ($/ft^2).
arguments.name: one_time_retrofit_cost_ip

arguments.display_name: Year to Incur One Time Retrofit Cost (whole years).
arguments.name: years_until_retrofit_cost

workflow.name: set_lighting_loads_by_lpd
workflow.description: Set the lighting power density (W/ft^2) in the to a specified value for all spaces that have lights. This can be applied to the entire building or a specific space type. Cost can be added per floor area

arguments.display_name: Add lights to all spaces included in floor area, including spaces that did not originally include lights
arguments.name: add_instance_all_spaces

arguments.display_name: Material and Installation Costs for Lights per Floor Area ($/ft^2).
arguments.name: material_cost

arguments.display_name: Demolition Costs for Lights per Floor Area ($/ft^2).
arguments.name: demolition_cost

arguments.display_name: Demolition Costs Occur During Initial Construction?
arguments.name: demo_cost_initial_const

arguments.display_name: O & M Costs for Lights per Floor Area ($/ft^2).
arguments.name: om_cost

workflow.name: ashrae_9012010_daylighting_control_with_run_switch
workflow.display_name: ASHRAE 90.1-2010 Daylighting Control with run switch
workflow.measure_definition_display_name: ASHRAE 90.1-2010 Daylighting Control with run switch
workflow.description: This measure adds automatic daylighting controls for Primary Sidelighted Areas and Toplighting according to ASHRAE 90.1-2010 sections 9.4.1.4 and 9.4.1.5.

workflow.name: controls_hwst_reset
workflow.description: This energy efficiency measure (EEM) adds a set point reset to all hot water loops present in the OpenStudio model. The hot water supply temperature reset will be based on outdoor-air temperature (OAT). The specific sequence is that as outdoor-air temperature (OAT) lowers from 60F (15.6C) down to 20F (-6.67C), the hot water supply temperature set point will increase from 160F (71.1C) up to 180F (82.2C).  This sequence provides a 20F (11.1C) change in the Hot Water Set Point, over a 40F (22.2C) temperature change in the OAT. This sequence assumes all boilers serving the hot water plant loops are non-condensing and should not receive return water below 140F (60.0C).

workflow.name: controls_hwpdp_reset
workflow.description: This energy efficiency measure (EEM) configures all variable or constant speed pumps identified as secondary hot water loop pumps. Identified pumps are then either replaced (in the case of a constant speed pump) or reconfigured (in the case of a variable speed pump) to operate as a variable speed pump with an aggressive Part Load Performance Curve representing operation of a functional hot water pump differential pressure reset control with a wide range of deviation in zone valve positions. Energy savings will be generated by operating the secondary hot water pump motor for longer periods of time at lower energy consumptive levels.

workflow.name: controls_chwst_reset
workflow.description: This energy efficiency measure (EEM) adds a set point reset to all chilled water loops present in the OpenStudio model. The chilled water supply temperature reset will be based on outdoor-air temperature (OAT). The specific sequence is that as outdoor-air temperature (OAT) rises from 60F (15.6C) up to 100F (37.8C), the chilled water supply temperature set point will decrease from 55F (12.8C) down to 45F (7.22C).  This sequence provides a 10F (15.6C) change in the Chilled Water Set Point, over a 40F (22.2C) temperature change in the OAT.

workflow.name: controls_chwpdp_reset
workflow.description: This energy efficiency measure (EEM) configures all variable or constant speed pumps identified as secondary chilled water loop pumps. Identified pumps are then either replaced (in the case of a constant speed pump) or reconfigured (in the case of a variable speed pump) to operate as a variable speed pump with an aggressive Part Load Performance Curve representing operation of a functional chilled water pump differential pressure reset control with a wide range of deviation in zone valve positions. Energy savings will be generated by operating the secondary chilled water pump motor for longer periods of time at lower energy consumptive levels.

workflow.name: controls_satoa_reset
workflow.description: Some buildings use a constant supply-air (also referred to discharge-air) temperature set point of 55F. When a building's supply fan system is operational, the supply-air temperature set point value should be automatically adjusting to internal/external conditions that will allow the supply fan to operate more efficiently. The simplest way to implement this strategy is to raise supply-air temperature when the outdoor air is cold and the building is less likely to need cooling.  Supplying this warmer air to the  terminals decreases the amount of reheat necessary at the terminal, saving heating energy.

workflow.name: controls_fanpressure_reset
workflow.description:
This measure changes the variable speed fan coefficients to model fan systems with different characteristics and static pressure reset controls.

Copies the NREL measure Change Variable Volume Fan Coefficients

arguments.display_name: Choose an Variable Volume Fan to change coefficients.
arguments.name: fan_choice

arguments.display_name: Choose fan coefficient set to use:
arguments.name: coeff_choice
arguments.default_value: Multi zone VAV with static pressure reset
arguments.value: Multi zone VAV with static pressure reset

workflow.name: enable_economizer_control_with_diffs
workflow.description:
There is currently not a functioning air side economizer enabled in the building. Air side economizers use cold outside air to either assist the mechanical cooling system, or if the air is cold enough, provide all of the cooling for a facility.









In order for an air side economizer to function properly, all of the outside air damper actuators need to have modulating capabilities. In addition to that, new control sequences need to be written into the building automation control system to enable the air-side economizer when outside air temperatures are below 60?F-65?F and the interior space temperatures are calling for cooling.









The building would realize the following operational benefits by utilizing an air-side economizer:




    -Reduction in cooling system energy use




    -Reduction in mechanical cooling system run time




    -Possible improvement in indoor air quality

workflow.name: enable_demand_controlled_ventilation
workflow.description: The facility currently does not have a demand controlled ventilation system or CO2 sensors in the air delivery system. Outside air is introduced and conditioned at a fixed rate based on the maximum design. Since the building occupancy fluctuates and is often less than the maximum design occupancy, it is being over-ventilated and consuming more energy than necessary. The building CO2 level is closely related to the occupancy. The typical outside CO2 level is relatively low concentration, around 400 to 500 ppm, and is used to dilute the higher indoor CO2 levels.Demand controlled ventilation could be implemented by deploying CO2 sensors located in each AHU return air duct and in densely occupied spaces, such as conference rooms. Implementation of this ECM will require:-Rebalance the open/closed outside air dampers to a lower minimum ventilation rate.-Program demand ventilation controls into each AHU, controlling modulating dampers in mixed air AHUs and VFDs in outside air units. Ventilation will be generally controlled from return air sensors, but will be increased as needed based on densely occupied space sensors.-Commission the project.

workflow.name: customize_prototype_tstats
workflow.description: A measure to inspect and edit the prototypical Tstat schedules for the OS Control Tool at VEIC

arguments.display_name: A swtich to turn off cooling
arguments.name: cooling_bool

workflow.description: This measure creates tariff objets from pre-poulated IDF files in the measures "resoruces" directory.

workflow.name: openstudio_results
workflow.description: This measure creates high level tables and charts pulling both from model inputs and EnergyPlus results. It has building level information as well as detail on space types, thermal zones, HVAC systems, envelope characteristics, and economics. Click the heading above a chart to view a table of the chart data.

arguments.display_name: Which Unit System do you want to use?
arguments.name: units

arguments.display_name: Report monthly fuel and enduse breakdown to registerValue
arguments.name: reg_monthly_details

workflow.description: foo

arguments.display_name: Coincident Peak Demand and Peak energy
arguments.name: coincident_section

options.name: Baseline
options.description: Option 2 Description: This energy efficiency measure (EEM) configures all variable or constant speed pumps identified as secondary chilled water loop pumps. Identified pumps are then either replaced (in the case of a constant speed pump) or reconfigured (in the case of a variable speed pump) to operate as a variable speed pump with an aggressive Part Load Performance Curve representing operation of a functional chilled water pump differential pressure reset control with a wide range of deviation in zone valve positions. Energy savings will be generated by operating the secondary chilled water pump motor for longer periods of time at lower energy consumptive levels.

options.name: Baseline
options.description: Option 2 Description: Some buildings use a constant supply-air (also referred to discharge-air) temperature set point of 55F. When a building's supply fan system is operational, the supply-air temperature set point value should be automatically adjusting to internal/external conditions that will allow the supply fan to operate more efficiently. The simplest way to implement this strategy is to raise supply-air temperature when the outdoor air is cold and the building is less likely to need cooling.  Supplying this warmer air to the  terminals decreases the amount of reheat necessary at the terminal, saving heating energy.

options.name: Baseline
options.description:
Option 2 Description: This measure changes the variable speed fan coefficients to model fan systems with different characteristics and static pressure reset controls.

Copies the NREL measure Change Variable Volume Fan Coefficients

options.name: Baseline
options.description:
Option 2 Description: There is currently not a functioning air side economizer enabled in the building. Air side economizers use cold outside air to either assist the mechanical cooling system, or if the air is cold enough, provide all of the cooling for a facility.









In order for an air side economizer to function properly, all of the outside air damper actuators need to have modulating capabilities. In addition to that, new control sequences need to be written into the building automation control system to enable the air-side economizer when outside air temperatures are below 60?F-65?F and the interior space temperatures are calling for cooling.









The building would realize the following operational benefits by utilizing an air-side economizer:




    -Reduction in cooling system energy use




    -Reduction in mechanical cooling system run time




    -Possible improvement in indoor air quality

options.name: Baseline
options.description: Option 2 Description: The facility currently does not have a demand controlled ventilation system or CO2 sensors in the air delivery system. Outside air is introduced and conditioned at a fixed rate based on the maximum design. Since the building occupancy fluctuates and is often less than the maximum design occupancy, it is being over-ventilated and consuming more energy than necessary. The building CO2 level is closely related to the occupancy. The typical outside CO2 level is relatively low concentration, around 400 to 500 ppm, and is used to dilute the higher indoor CO2 levels.Demand controlled ventilation could be implemented by deploying CO2 sensors located in each AHU return air duct and in densely occupied spaces, such as conference rooms. Implementation of this ECM will require:-Rebalance the open/closed outside air dampers to a lower minimum ventilation rate.-Program demand ventilation controls into each AHU, controlling modulating dampers in mixed air AHUs and VFDs in outside air units. Ventilation will be generally controlled from return air sensors, but will be increased as needed based on densely occupied space sensors.-Commission the project.

options.name: Baseline
options.description: Option 1 Description: This measure creates high level tables and charts pulling both from model inputs and EnergyPlus results. It has building level information as well as detail on space types, thermal zones, HVAC systems, envelope characteristics, and economics. Click the heading above a chart to view a table of the chart data.
